:''For other uses, see [[South's Oldest Rivalry (disambiguation)]].'' {| id="toc" style="float:right; margin-left: 1em; margin-bottom: 1em; text-align: left" |+ Richmond â William & Mary Rivalry |- | align="center" style="width:13em" | [[Image:Richmond Spiders text logo.svg|120px|Richmond logo]] | align="center" style="width:13em" | [[Image:New William & Mary Logo.gif|140px|William & Mary logo]] |- {{#if: {{{image location|}}} | {{!}} style="text-align: center;" colspan="2" {{!}} }} |- | '''Teams''' | [[Richmond Spiders football|Richmond Spiders]]
[[William & Mary Tribe football|William & Mary Tribe]] |- | '''Originated''' | 1898 |- | '''Series''' | W&M leads 61â55â5{{ref|1|1}} |- | '''Largest Victory''' | 48 (twice)
1907, 1916 |- | '''Highest Scoring Game''' | W&M 59, RIC 21
November 22, 2003 |- | '''Most Recent Game''' | W&M 25, RIC 23
November 19, 2011 |- | '''Current Win Streak''' | William & Mary 2 |- | '''Trophy''' | Capital Cup |} Coined as the "South's Oldest Rivalry," the '''Capital Cup''' is one of the longest-running [[college football]] rivalries in the [[United States]]. Contested yearly between the [[University of Richmond]] [[Richmond Spiders football|Spiders]] and [[The College of William & Mary|College of William & Mary]] [[William & Mary Tribe|Tribe]], only four rivalries have more games played. ==History== The '''Capital Cup''' is one of the oldest collegiate American Football rivalries, played between the [[University of Richmond]] [[Richmond Spiders football|Spiders]] and [[The College of William & Mary|College of William & Mary]] [[William & Mary Tribe|Tribe]]. The yearly contest is tied for fourth most occurrences, currently standing at 119 times. Played nearly continuously since 1898, there have only been three years that the game did not occur: 1900, 1902 and 1943.[http://www.thecollegianur.com/2008/11/22/ur-defeats-william-mary-23-20/ ''The Collegian'' â UR defeats W&M 23-20]. Retrieved on November 28, 2008. The game had until recently been dubbed the '''I-64 Bowl''', from 1984 though 2008. Beginning in 2009, however, the game was officially renamed the Capital Cup, for which a new trophy was created.{{ref|2|2}} The '''Capital Cup''' name was chosen to honor the entire 119-game history of the rivalry between the two schools and the status of the two cities as the two historical capitals of the Commonwealth of Virginia. The match is typically played as the final regular season game for both teams, but for many years used to be played on [[Thanksgiving Day]]. The November 21, 2009 game marked the 119th meeting between the schools.[http://richmondspiders.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/recaps/112208aaa.html RichmondSpiders.com]. "...Saturday in the 118th meeting between long-time rivals at [[Zable Stadium]] in Williamsburg." Retrieved on November 28, 2008. The 13â10 Richmond win placed the all-time record at 59â55â5, remaining in favor of William & Mary.{{ref|3|3}} The Richmond Spiders won this inaugural Capital Cup by a final score of 13â10, simultaneously giving Richmond a share of the [[Colonial Athletic Association]] season championship. Place kicker Andrew Howard converted a game-winning 48-yard field goal as time expired. Then, in 2010, William & Mary clinched a share of the conference with the Capital Cup win. The Tribe had to beat Richmond and have Villanova upset Delaware in order to share the championship with Delaware, and both of those results occurred. ==Trophy== The '''I-64 Trophy''' was a [[college football]] trophy that went to the winner of the annual [[College of William & Mary]] versus [[University of Richmond]] football game from 1984 through 2008.[http://www.1122productions.com/rivalries/r.html College Football Rivalries Q-R]. Retrieved on November 27, 2008.[http://www.richmondspiders.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/111109aaa.html Richmond, William & Mary Rename Football Rivalry As Capital Cup]. Retrieved on November 11, 2009.[http://richmondspiders.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/111108aag.html Richmond Spiders Athletic Site]. "Up Next: The Spiders bring the 2008 regular-season to a close next Saturday with the I-64 Trophy on the line at William & Mary." Retrieved on November 28, 2008. Both [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] schools participate in the [[NCAA]] [[Football Championship Subdivision#Football Championship Subdivision|Football Championship Subdivision]] (formerly Division I-AA). The name for the trophy came from [[Interstate 64 in Virginia|Interstate 64]], which connects the schools through the short distance between [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]] and [[Williamsburg, Virginia|Williamsburg]]. The I-64 Trophy was replaced in 2009 with the '''Capital Cup''', which honors the entire 118-game history of the rivalry between the two schools and the status of the two cities as the last two capitals of the Commonwealth of Virginia. ==Game results== ''Richmond victories are shaded ââ blue. William & Mary victories shaded in ââ green. color: #FFD700" | November 19, 2011 || '''William & Mary''' || '''25''' || Richmond || 23 || Richmond || W&M || 61â55â5 |} ==Game MVPs== A Capital Cup [[Most Valuable Player]] (MVP) Award was created beginning with the 2009 match-up, coinciding with the renaming to the Capital Cup.[http://www.richmondspiders.com/sports/m-footbl/spec-rel/thecapitalcup.html All-time results]. University of Richmond Spiders football. Retrieved on November 12, 2009. {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" width="100%" style="font-size:90%;" |- ! Season ! MVP ! Team ! Position ! class="unsortable" | Notes |-align=center | [[2009 NCAA Division I FCS football season|2009]] | {{sortname|Eric|Ward|nolink=1}} | [[2009 Richmond Spiders football team|Richmond]] | [[Quarterback]] | align=left | Completed 24 of 36 passes (66.7%) for 221 yards |-align=center | [[2010 NCAA Division I FCS football season|2010]] | {{sortname|Mike|Callahan|nolink=1}} | [[2010 William & Mary Tribe football team|William & Mary]] | [[Quarterback]] | align=left | Completed 17 of 22 passes (77.2%) for a career-high 331 yards and two touchdowns |-align=center | [[2011 NCAA Division I FCS football season|2011]] | {{sortname|Jonathan|Grimes|nolink=1}} | [[2011 William & Mary Tribe football team|William & Mary]] | [[Running back]] | align=left | Attempted school-record 39 rushes for 205 yards and one touchdown |} ==See also== * [[List of NCAA college football rivalry games]] ==Notes== *{{note|1|1}} During the early twentieth century, William & Mary and Richmond would occasionally play two or even three times per season since there were so few teams in the area. Thus it is not a mistake if the W-L column has identical years in them (the teams may have split the season 1â1, for example). *{{note|2|2}} Only [[Lafayette College|Lafayette]]â[[Lehigh University|Lehigh]], [[Princeton University|Princeton]]â[[Yale University|Yale]], and [[Harvard University|Harvard]]âYale have played more games; [[University of Minnesota|Minnesota]]â[[University of WisconsinâMadison|Wisconsin]] is tied for fourth with this series. *{{note|3|3}} The 2008 game was the first in the history of the rivalry to be decided in overtime. Richmond would go on to win the 2008 [[NCAA Division I Football Championship]] by defeating the [[Montana Grizzlies football|Montana Grizzlies]] 24â7. It was the first team national championship for Richmond in any sport. ==References== {{reflist}} {{William & Mary Tribe Football}} {{Richmond Spiders Football}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Capital Cup}} [[Category:College football rivalries in the United States]] [[Category:College football rivalry trophies in the United States]] [[Category:Richmond Spiders football]] [[Category:William & Mary Tribe football]] [[Category:Awards established in 1898]] [[Category:Recurring sporting events established in 1898]]
